info.game_comments:
David Madden game 1.
All but two responses (and a few category names) 7 letters long.

(1, 1).clue: The Meiji reforms of the 19th century permanently abolished this Japanese warrior class

(2, 1).clue: It was the nickname of Alan Alda's character on "M*A*S*H"

(3, 1).clue: Hungarian cuisine uses this orange-red spice as a mainstay flavoring

(4, 1).clue: This state bordering Canada is known as "Big Sky Country"

(5, 1).clue: In the 1930s, with its top-loading model, Swingline revolutionized this device

(6, 1).clue: A "Holly Jolly Christmas" would become this, "con acebo y alegre"

(1, 2).clue: In 1966 this university's Public Policy program became the Kennedy School of Government

(2, 2).clue: On this sitcom, a "how-to" book author buys a Vermont inn & moves there

(3, 2).clue: Wontons & kreplach are similar in design to this Italian specialty, filled pillows of pasta

(4, 2).clue: Warm Springs in this state was home to FDR's Little White House

(5, 2).clue: Wimmer-Ferguson makes a toy for babies to bite on punningly called the "Brain" this

(6, 2).clue: This word for a bar or tavern has moved from Spanish into English dictionaries

(1, 3).clue: One of France's major ports, it was the site of the 1940 evacuation of more than 300,000 men

(3, 3).clue: In the same family as the peach, it has been grown in China for over 3,000 years

(4, 3).clue: Its state flower is the saguaro cactus blossom

(5, 3).clue: A hacker called "Captain Crunch" found one of these, in a cereal box, whose tone could manipulate phone lines

(6, 3).clue: A flamboyant & risky job, it's also a word that means "killer"

(1, 4).clue: In February 1790 this man presided over the first meeting of the Supreme Court

(3, 4).clue: The name of this fancy dish seen here comes from a word that means "to blow"

(4, 4).clue: This state trademarked the logo seen here

(5, 4).clue: Used to serve a particular type of liquor, it's the glass seen here

(6, 4).clue: A wine concoction, it's also a word that can mean "bloodletting"

(1, 5).clue: The cathedral of this city in Spain claims to hold the remains of Christopher Columbus, moved there in 1899

(2, 5).clue: Married name of Miss MacGillicuddy in a '50s sitcom

(3, 5).clue: The name of this type of small quick bread comes from the French for "twice cooked"

(4, 5).clue: Helen Keller was born in a house named Ivy Green in Tuscumbia in this state

(5, 5).clue: Many car owners have this device with a spherical cap on one end & a sliding scale on the other

(6, 5).clue: In old Mexico a criollo was of European descent & this was a person of mixed European & native blood

(1, 1).clue: A deuterium atom is a hydrogen atom that has this keeping its proton company in the nucleus

(2, 1).clue: If you "can't smile without" the singer of "Copacabana", go to this last name.com, his official website

(3, 1).clue: 20 years after it was formed, this Korean company became a success in the U.S. with the 1986 Excel

(4, 1).clue: His last novel, "A Passage to India", is considered his masterwork

(5, 1).clue: From Aramaic & Hebrew words, this title of the savior of the Jews means "anointed one"

(6, 1).clue: Harsh way Tom Swift told a music student, "You played that note a half step too high"

(1, 2).clue: This largest nerve in the body arises in the sacral plexus, leaves the pelvis & runs down the thigh

(2, 2).clue: In November of 2000 Bobby Brown & this singer held their first joint concert at the Aladdin in Vegas

(3, 2).clue: The Boxster and the 911 are popular models from this automaker

(4, 2).clue: He created the Nadsat language for his novel "A Clockwork Orange"

(5, 2).clue: Also a caste, it's a Hindu priest or scholar of Vedic literature

(6, 2).clue: "I feel like a Native American warrior", said Tom in this courageous manner

(1, 3).clue: Bears appeared during this epoch right before the Pliocene

(2, 3).clue: In 1984 she had her first Top 10 hit in the U.S. with "Borderline"

(3, 3).clue: This '70s model from American Motors sounds like an imp that used to torment WWII aircraft

(4, 3).clue: At the start of a novel by this author, Dombey is 48 years old & son, 48 minutes

(5, 3).clue: Think "fast": the name of this month in the Islamic calendar is from the Arabic for "to be scorched"

(6, 3).clue: When he said, "We'll have to cross a treeless expanse of land", Tom spoke this way, very simply

(1, 4).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew reports from a classroom.)  Meaning not at a right angle, it can refer to slanting abdominal muscles, or a geometric angle like this

(2, 4).clue: This singer played detective Foxxy Cleopatra in the third "Austin Powers" movie

(3, 4).clue: With its GT and GTS versions, this model from Mitsubishi is blocking out a lot of the competition

(4, 4).clue: He wrote the poem "Gunga Din" to honor the Bhisti, the natives who aided British soldiers in India

(5, 4).clue: This eighth incarnation of Vishnu is often depicted as a young cowherd

(6, 4).clue: It's the shrewd way in which Tom said, "We'll seal all our food in metal containers"

(1, 5).clue: It equals mass divided by volume & is often expressed in pounds per cubic foot

(2, 5).clue: This one-named singer, whose name means "most exalted one" in Swahili, tragically died in a plane crash in 2001

(3, 5).clue: In 1965 Ralph Nader declared that this model from Chevrolet was "Unsafe at Any Speed"

(4, 5).clue: This 19th century English author also wrote the books "Curiosa Mathematica" & "Symbolic Logic"

(5, 5).clue: Incorporating elements of Islam & others, this religion was founded in Iran in 1863

(6, 5).clue: "I have no idea how to fill in the empty line", Tom said this way

(0, 0).clue: The Victoria Cross is made from metal taken from enemy guns captured in this war
